Doc ID: 7409, distribution: 0.5569418503979711 ; the last time i worked out in our home gym was when i was , after weight restoring and being on absolute exercise restriction for  straight months.
.
.
when i finally reintroduced movement, i had no idea how to do so with grace. i would wake up at  AM to put in a two hour circuit, forcing myself through reps on an empty stomach, wishing i was anywhere but here.
.
.
then i would shower, climb back into bed, and wake around noon for a second workout in this same gym. a long distance run. i hated every second.
.
.
i haven't worked out down here since. today, in the midst of the quarantine chaos, i laced up my sneakers and headed down the stairs. i tied my hair in a ponytail and stared at myself in the mirror. i swore for myself i'd bring happiness and light to this once-toxic space. to this forgotten war zone, where i waged battle against myself every day, twice a day, for years.
.
.
i didn't follow a guide or a streamed workout. i simply turned up my music and had FUN. i lifted things and put them down. i jumped around. i stopped to dance. i took  minutes to be in my own company and to move with love, for myself, an expression of gratitude for all the growth i've undergone.
.
.
today i healed. today i loved. this epidemic, this chaos, this quarantine. it's devastating and flipping all of our lives upside down. but for me, today, it was a small blessing in disguise. it forced me to confront the lingering corners of a dark past, and flash a light into them.
.
.
for the next few days all heal at our own pace be kind. be gentle. be patient.

Plus, it's normal to have fat on your belly. Please don't be so hard on yourself!!

Do I regret all the yummy food, social drinks with friends, the laughs, the dancing, the deep conversations & being fully present while I'm out at dinnerâ€¦ all because it means I have a bloated belly throughout the night? Doc ID: 8109, distribution: 0.5552763409049151 ; sleep.
.
it's been an enemy of mine for some time now. you would think working full time with a  hour round trip commute every day would make hitting the pillow extremely easy. i wish! even if i'm terribly exhausted, falling and staying asleep are struggles for me. im constantly looking for new ways to enhance my abilities to fall asleep as well as the quality of my sleep. 
so when i came across an article that my friends over at @thethirty put together on a sleep trick, i was intriguing. and desperate. .
have you heard of the // trick? i hadn't until i read about it. the article explains it best, but essentially this is a breathing trick that forces your heart rate down. doing so allows your body to prepare for sleep. you take  seconds to inhale a deep, deep breath. then you hold that breath for  slow seconds. finally you release the breath slowly, using  full counts. the first time i tried this, on around  or  seconds of the exhale, i literally felt my muscles loosen. the fist i was unaware i was holding under my pillow actually released itself. i felt like i melted into my sheets. .
and hours later...i woke up.
i had fallen asleep within minutes. and i didn't wake up countless times during the night. i realize this sounds absurd. magical even. .
but simply forcing my body to prepare for rest was all i needed to do to cross the bridge into sleep. i'll be completely honest and say this works  times out of . there are still nights where i'm restless and lose plenty of sleep. but i wanted to share this trick with you all because it has helped me immensely! .
i also find a five minute deep stretch before bed to help me get into a state that's prepared for sleep. on days where i cant tackle my racing mind i rub lavender oil on my chest and wrists and have found success with that as well!
.
what are your bedtime tips and tricks for falling asleep? i'd love to hear them! .
.
.
.
.

#sleep #healthy #foodie #foodblogger #sleeptricks #bettersleep #decor #urbanoutfitters #bedroominspo #anthropolgie #roominspo #bedroom #plantbasedblogger #wellness #healthyinspo #healthylife

Doc ID: 9396, distribution: 0.8691430798408426 ; mental health awareness month â¤ï¸â€ğŸ©¹

i'm claire, and i'm depressed. a lot of you probably know that i've struggled with depression, anxiety, and eating disorders because i've typically always been pretty open about my mental health journey and recovery on this platform. but lately, i haven't talked about what i'm going through as much on here, and that's because sharing that i'm struggling with my mental well-being in ways i thought i was over is hard.

especially as someone who's always preached self-worth, self-love, self-kindness, and self-acceptance, it's hard to admit that a lot of days, i feel like a worthless mess. it's hard to admit that i haven't been keeping myself accountable with meds/doctor appointments. it's hard to admit that eating has been my primary coping mechanism the past few months. it's hard to admit that sometimes, i let my mind beat myself up.

but, here's the thing. healing isn't a one and done type of thing. our lives aren't stagnant. new challenges, new situations, and new circumstances are all things that might bring up old feelings or coping mechanisms, and that's okay. struggling with your mental health isn't something to be ashamed of, and being vulnerable about it is a strength, not a weakness. i read something that said that this time you're not starting over from scratch- you're starting over from experience, and i felt that.

to anyone who feels like they're stuck in their journey, starting over with their healing, struggling with their mental health, or fighting a battle that other people don't know about or just don't understand, i see you, i'm with you, and i support you.

swipe for some words that have been speaking to me lately â€”>

I grew up fearing food, restricting it â€” then inadvertently overindulging, not understanding how the food I ate affected my body & constantly feeling guilty after eating. So I just wanted to leave this here in case you're feeling the same way. This is the difference your food intake can makeâ€¦

On the left, I was working out at the gym BUT I wasn't giving my body enough fuel to build or even maintain my muscle mass, I felt weaker & hungrier.

On the right, I'm still resistance training the same amount of days per week BUT eating more, feeling stronger, I have more energy & give my body sufficient energy to build / maintain my muscle mass.

Without eating enough, your body can barely carry out its basic functions; breathing, brain function, pumping blood, digestion, etcâ€¦ Let alone give you the energy to exercise, socialise, focus, laugh & enjoy lifeâ€¦ Which are all things your body has the energy to do when you give it enough food to THRIVE on.

This isn't about one body type being better than the other, it's about the lifestyle FEELING better â€” having more food flexibility, not ignoring hunger cues, feeling stronger, enjoying life more. This is here to show you the difference fuelling your body properly can make ğŸ¥²

It isn't the enemy, it's ENERGY. 

It also goes to show that copying someone else's routine doesn't mean you'll have the same results as them! So many different factors are at play:

ğŸ diet - the type of food you eat + the amount of food you eat
ğŸ§¬ genetic makeup - some bodies are naturally leaner, some build muscle mass easier, some have longer torsos, wider hips, etc
ğŸ•ºğŸ¼ exercise - the intensity, frequency & type of exercise you do
ğŸ’¤ sleep / stress / etc â€” this varies for all of us. Even if we ate & exercised the same, we'd all look different. 

Moral of the story isâ€¦ Your body can't run on an empty tank. Instead of focusing on how your body & life looks, think about how it FEELS ğŸ’—

 â€¢ BE COLD ALL THE TIME! - even ifÂ you haven't experienced large drops of body fat orÂ weight.  â€¢ BRUISE EASILY! - Its enough just to pinch your thigh and congrats, your legs are officially purple. Caused by low blood sugar and lack of vitamin B in your system. 
 â€¢ BE THIRSTY EVEN THO YOU JUST DRANK! - aw man, it must be so fun to constantly shock your body like this. You can go through  bottles of water and still have dry mouth. Unexplained but could be a sign of diabetes. Drink liquid magnesium, it makes a huge difference! (cal) 
 â€¢ STANDING UP AND PASSING OUT! - you get used to it but its always a nice shocker. I'm pretty sure we all look insane when we stand up and then grab the nearest thing to hold onto. This is called orthostatic hypotension and occurs when a person's blood pressure falls when suddenly standing up from a lying or sitting down position.

Doc ID: 9148, distribution: 0.16533824145704334 ; here's a story about my love for fruit toasts:
.
â €â €â €â €â €â €â €â €â €
my dad used to make me breakfast every morning when i was a kid. he always had some culinary art or experiment to serve me (usually an omelet made up of leftovers-- it was like his own Chopped challenge). when i say every morning, i mean e v e r y m o r n i n g before he dropped me off at school. that is, until i was introduced to the toast + nut butter + fruit combination. as soon as my brother showed me the ropes on how to toast bread until warm and crisp, spread a smooth layer of sticky thick peanut butter on the bread and then top it with banana slices, i could NOT get enough. sorry dad... but at least you were able to rest a little bit more in the morning .
i used to think i was super fancy but then food photography came to instagram and the gastronomic versions of toast or breakfast emerged. despite that, i'm not hard to please. somehow my level of fancy is pretty much most people's low end. but fancy isn't really my goal. it's the combination of the warm, crisp but soft bread, with the salty savory nut butter and the almost tart, mostly sweet fruit accent on top that grounds me. it takes me back to the days i would get ready for school early enough to beat my dad to the kitchen and make us some toast so that we could enjoy this wonderful combination together.
.
(ps- i really looked up "food jags" in my nutrition text book to make sure it isn't disordered behavior because i swear i'll eat other food but this is just so good + easy to me that it's my first choice lately every day haha)

Doc ID: 9748, distribution: 0.5958075484608221 ; on social media, we have the power to choose who we follow and interact with, and that's really neat! for a long time, i felt like i needed to unfollow anyone who didn't share the exact same values and opinions as me because i was worried about feeling triggered.  now, i realize that there can be a lot of value in following a diverse array of accounts and hearing other people's perspectives whether or not they are similar to mine.  hearing someone else's different opinion doesn't mean i change mine, but it helps me learn about the complexities on certain issues, keeps me humble, and reminds me that everyone's human.

HOWEVER, there's a huge difference between someone having a different opinion from you and someone making you feel bad for having the opinion that you do. it is % okay (and expected) to disagree with someone else's opinions or for someone else to disagree with you. no one is better or worse for that. what isn't okay is making people with different perspectives feel less than because of it, and if someone you are following on social media makes you doubt your own worth, tries to instill their beliefs in you, is causing distress, or simply isn't serving you in any way, it isn't worth it, and you have the power to set the boundary you need.

as humans, we are complex, diverse, and multi-dimensional people, and our opinions, which are formed by our own individual experiences, reflect that. despite our differences, we are all doing best in this world, and that is going to look different person to person.

reminders:
. social media is what you make of it.
. choose kindness.

my monday morning thoughts are accompanied by a picture of the tres leches cake i made this weekend and am having slice of as part of my breakfast! anyone else eat leftover cake for breakfast?

You don't have to come up with the solution in the first conversation, and it's probably best if you don't approach it with a â€œthe current set up isn't fairâ€ (even if you don't think it is!) Doc ID: 2684, distribution: 0.4479211989436167 ; Sorry to break it to you but YOU CAN'T HATE YOUR BODY INTO A SHAPE YOU WILL LOVE... ğŸ˜¦

I spent most of my life abusing my body with unloving thoughts & fad diets (& I know I'm not the only one), so I feel like it's important to share some of the things that finally helped me change my mindset & lifestyle FOR GOOD! â¤µï¸

- you can't hate your body into a shape you will love, showing some love to the body you're in is much more effective
- exercise in ways you enjoy and because you CAN (what a blessing), not because you 'have to'!
- if your goal is weight loss, learn about calorie deficits... To lose weight you must consume less calories than you burn each day. This means you can still eat the foods you enjoy so long as you remain in a calorie deficit
- fuel your body with nutritious foods & allow yourself to enjoy a meal you crave every day. Remember, this needs to be sustainable!!! So going cold turkey & cutting out your fav foods will never work long-term. If you still enjoy a treat each day, you won't feel like you're missing out, feel guilty about it or be tempted to throw in the towel & binge
- remember that it won't happen overnight, but it WILL happen so long as you keep at it ğŸŒŸ
- one 'bad' meal doesn't mean you have to have a bad day... 
- eating too little can actually slow your metabolism, stall weight loss & harm your health long-term... Please eat enough ğŸ’›
- it takes an excess of , calories ON TOP OF the calories your body burns each day for you to gain a kilo... So no, over-eating on one day won't make you gain weight! But over-eating consistently will. 
- rest is just as important for success, your body needs time to recover! It goes through a lot every day just to keep you alive ğŸŒŸ
- the scales are fickle & unpredictable, the numbers will change day-to-day due to your hormones, if your muscles are inflamed, if you're dehydrated, if you've eaten a lot of sodium, etc so please don't let this determine how you feel about yourself! 

I hope this helps in some way?! Lmk if it does! No matter what your health goals are... You've got this! ğŸ¥°

#healthylifestyle #health #healthhacks #bikini #weightlosstips #weightloss

Doc ID: 7728, distribution: 0.6611018238493469 ; i don't remember how i began telling my story, or when. i can't recall which pieces dropped first, which corners of my heart bled out and found light beyond my chest.
.
it simply happened when i was ready.
.
eating disorders, like all  traumas, are deeply intimate. when i was sick i went to humiliating lengths to obey an illness. i was irrational, irritable, rude. for years i was embarrassed of who i once was and the struggle that shaped me. i wanted to bury my past and move on.
.
but with time comes acceptance. as i forged deeper into recovery, i found a new love for life that starkly contrasted the darkness of years past. my life grew brighter. i realized how powerful this transition was and i itched to share it. .
it felt selfish to hold this in, keep my story a secret when i could help someone find their way out. .
.
so i spoke up.
.
i knew i was ready because the heart with which i viewed my ED with underwent a shift. instead of understanding my disorder as a humiliating character flaw, i saw it for what it truly was: a tragedy out of my control and nothing more. not a choice, not my identity.
.
with acceptance i found a voice. i could easily use before/after photos to tell my story, but words are more powerful. i can use them to deeply convey  the pain and fear, the strength and resilience, every inch of the process from hurt to healed. my story is more than a physical manifestation.
.
if you have a story and want to share it:
*reach a place of stability before opening up. you may be too fragile right now. that's okay. don't rush.
*dismiss the idea that your story isn't â€œgood enoughâ€. that you weren't â€œsick enoughâ€ or didn't endure â€œenoughâ€. *know that being vulnerable makes you stronger. courage isn't crafted in a place of comfort.
.
one thing i will say is that you can't let fear of judgement hold you back. there is not a rational soul out there that will blame YOU for your struggle. i used to be ashamed of my past. now? thousands of strangers know that i used to smash bowls of oatmeal on the floor to avoid eating. im not embarrassed by the pain i went through. i'm empowered by my ability to rise above it.
.
if you're ready, tell me...what's your story?

Doc ID: 9562, distribution: 0.310168329542822 ; i get told that my body â€œlooksâ€ â€œhealthyâ€ and â€œathleticâ€ by family, by friends, and by complete strangers...a lot. i know that they're meant as compliments, but please hear me out.

my body has looked bigger than my current body, smaller than my current body, and similar to my current body, and i've been very unhealthy and less athletic than i am now with all of them.

my body has also looked bigger than my current body and smaller than my current body, and i've been more athletic than i am now with them.

over the past couple years, my body has looked relatively the same, and even then, my health and athleticism has changed throughout.

the point? how my body looks has never been an indicator of my health or athleticism. but, comments about my body and how it looks has previously led me to tie my identity to my body, to restrict myself in order to achieve a look (that was never enough), and to prioritize â€œlooking healthyâ€ over actually being healthy.

i know i have body privilege, and so many people who are also healthy experience weight stigma. even though this is what my healthy recovered body looks like (right now), this is not what your healthy body should look like because all of our healthy bodies are going to look different from one another.

some reminders:
- people of all shapes and sizes can be healthy and athletic. health and athleticism are not a look.
- you can choose to add in health-promoting behaviors to your lifestyle without any focus on your weight.
- we can't dismantle diet culture without addressing weight stigma.
- you are not what other people think of you.
- if we all ate the same things and exercised the same ways, we'd all still have different bodies.
- someone else's body doesn't tell you anything about them.
- there are better compliments than ones about someone's body.
- how we look is one of the least important things about ourselves.

p.s. you are not morally obligated to be healthy or athletic. ALL bodies are good bodies that are deserving of care, love, and respect.

p.p.s. you can live in a privileged body and still struggle with an eating disorder, body image, and negative comments from others about your body. 
------------------------------------------------------------

Doc ID: 9917, distribution: 0.5532601704563789 ; when my eating disorder and restriction were at their worst, my weight was at its heaviest.
â€”â€”
a lot of times, we think eating disorders and restriction, and we think weight loss, underweight and frail bodies, amenorrhea, hair loss, etc. because that's what's most often portrayed in the media.  people who experience all of those have very valid stories, but eating disorders can also look really different from that too.
â€”â€”
when i first started restricting my food  years ago, i dropped a lot of really fast. i experienced a lot of those symptoms i just listed.  but, when i weight restored, it wasn't because i had chosen recovery- it was because the restriction had developed into binge eating disorder.  i was stuck in the binge and restriction cycle for years (restricting daily and binging nightly), and at my rock bottom, i had gained double the amount of weight i had initially lost, had high blood pressure, had pre-diabetic blood sugar levels, was mentally restricting the most i ever had, yet was eating ,+ calories almost daily, and was filled with self-hatred and guilt.  the worst part? no one in my life even knew what i was doing except for me.
â€”â€”
now, years filled with ups and downs later, i am ~ pounds lighter than my heaviest weight (interestingly, around the same weight as before my initial restriction), not from restricting, but as a side effect of FOOD FREEDOM and ALLOWING myself to eat whatever and whenever i want. funny how that works, right?
side note: as many of you know, i am currently on a weight gain journey, but it doesn't have to do with my past with disordered eating.
â€”â€”
i don't talk much about these parts of my disorder and recovery much because honestly, i worry that i'll be discredited and that my story won't be viewed as valid because my recovery involved weight loss.  but, this is my story, and i share it to remind you that eating disorders don't have a look, you are worthy of help no matter how much you eat or weigh, and your story and journey are valid even if you feel alone.

Doc ID: 18319, distribution: 0.8827975407867906 ; dainty-disgrace:   I think a lot of people forget to talk about how time becomes the enemy when you have an eating disorder. Two hours to a normal person could be excitement getting off work or going out with friends when it can be total, utter agony to someone with an eating disorder. Two hours until you can eat an apple. Two hours until you have to go out to eat with family. Two hours of total panic. A day to a normal person usually means nothing. Work. Hobbies. Or just a day reading a good book. To someone with an eating disorder it can be counting the hours until you get that -hour fast and listing all the things to do just so you wouldn't binge. Just don't binge, you keep telling yourself over and over again. And the day seems to last forever. Three weeks to a normal person go by just like nothing. They go by fast if there's going to be a fun beach trip with friends and it'll be even fun. They barely even think about the passing time. To someone with an eating disorder, more panic, counting the days in agony. Counting how much weight you have to, absolutely have to, lose until that trip. How much weight you can lose in a week? How about a day?  completely obsessive days. You have to reach that gw in that time so you can look good in a bikini. And when it comes, you haven't reached your gw and you cry about the three weeks you just wasted,  days lost, and even if you did reach it, you wouldn't be comfortable enough to wear that bikini anyway. So you obsess about the next  days. And so on and so on. And just like that, time has become numbers too.

Doc ID: 17104, distribution: 1.0 ; Question: Is it honestly out of control to have a muffin and a bar? I know it's more than you would usually choose to eat but it isn't excessive in objective terms. Answer: I think that's exactly what I wrote in my post?? That I know it's not excessive overall but it's the out of control feeling in my brain that's awful. Maybe if you've never experienced it, you can't comprehend how horrible it is, or maybe that it's even possible for your brain to go on a rampage that you can't stop. Perhaps you think that's ridiculous, of course you can just choose not to do it. That's what's awful about it, even while a bit of your brain is telling you that, the rest of your brain is away, in the shop, buying the food, eating it as fast as it can. If I tried to explain it with science, I'd say that spend a long enough time with a restrictive eating disorder and survival pathways in your brain open up that decide you will take in enough nutrition to survive no matter what. It's instinctive. And even after you've been eating regularly and adequately for a long time, occasionally the door to those pathways gets thrown open and away your brain goes into frenzied survival mode again.What I want to try and do is build some new neural pathways to get out of that survival mode because right now I don't seem to have a way to stop it other than to hang on for the ride until it's over.

Doc ID: 9843, distribution: 0.7054564352191357 ; when you let go of restriction, you might only want to eat everything you restricted yourself from...a lot of it, and that's normal and okay.
â€”â€”
your body is SO SMART, has no ulterior motives, and truly just wants the best for you, i promise. so, give yourself permission to honor its desires in their ENTIRETY.
â€”â€”
i used to think that i could live a more free life by just adjusting my food rules. instead of  calories, i'd eat  calories. when that didn't work, i moved my calorie â€œallowanceâ€ to  then to  then to  up until i told myself, okay claire, just eat under  calories a day. that's a ton, so you can do that right?? NOPEEE.  because even though that was maybe enough calories for me, since i still had a set of rules, and was mentally restricting, i was still struggling, still binging, and still food-focused.  as @talyngracee put it the other day, you're just moving from a smaller cage to a bigger cage. you're still in a cage, and you're still being controlled.
â€”â€”
while this doesn't apply to everyone, it is normal to want to eat A LOT of food when you initially let go of restriction, and that's because your body needs to learn how to trust you again. it needs to trust that you don't want to starve it, it needs to trust that you will listen to the cues it sends you, and it needs to trust that you trust it back because like in any healthy relationship, trust is earned and a two way street.
â€”â€”
i think food structure helps a lot of people with their schedule, budget, understanding what food combos fuel them best, lack of hunger cues, etc., but when working towards freedom, it's important to get real with yourself about the WHY behind your choices.  with food freedom comes LIFE freedom, and that's worth fighting for.
â€”â€”
p.s. poutine is f-ing great

Doc ID: 8922, distribution: 0.44217196744050374 ; is it possible to start intuitive eating without gaining weight? let's dive into it!

Intuitive Eating is a self-care eating framework, which brings together instinct, emotion, and rational thought. 

Unlike diets, it doesn't guarantee weight loss/gain 

We all have unique set points- a preset weight baseline wired to our DNA. 

Just like we all have unique foot sizes and shapes, we all have unique waist sizes and weights. 

The first step to intuitive eating is actually to reject the Diet Mentality. this step requires that any goals of weight loss be put on the back burner or eliminated right away because the motivation to lose weight can interfere with the process. imagine you are trying to reject the diet mentality but so focused on losing weight that anything which ~isn't~ a diet doesn't seem feasible for you.

focusing on weight loss also gets in the way of finally making peace with foods that you find yourself restricting and then binging later after your efforts to never eat carbs again goes to ğŸ’©

a part of Making Peace with Food for many (including myself) is weight gain, because they are finally eating what they've restricted for so long. eventually they get over the allure and realize it doesn't feel so great to eat a whole cake all the time.

in order to GET to that step and to feel like you are finally not controlled by your "cravings," however, you HAVE to let go of wanting to lose weight.

the good news is: along the way you learn how to Respect your Hunger & Fullness, Cope w/ Emotions Without Food, and incorporate movement you truly enjoy

Many actually end up effortlessly losing weight after the gain because they find they actually don't want to eat that whole chocolate cake every night and it was the â€œrulesâ€ that made it seem so enticing.

Some might gain weight & keep it - mostly because they were trying so hard to maintain a shape that wasn't meant for them. 

Intuitive Eating teaches that it wouldn't be fair to ourselves and our quality of life to try to fit a certain shape- just like it wouldn't be fair to try squeezing on a pair of size  shoes as a person with size  feet.

you won't have to follow anyone else's plan but your own ;) 
------------------------------------------------------------

Doc ID: 2359, distribution: 1.0 ; Eating for balance AND enjoyment because both are important, and we LOVE fuelling our bodies around here!!

For a really long time, I saw food as this thing that I constantly craved but ignored... Something that held power over me & made me feel incredibly guilty... Something that I relied on for comfort, so-much-so I'd continue to eat until my tummy felt super uncomfortable, or on the other end of the spectrum, would restrict & not allow myself to have certain foods at all.

If you've had a tricky relationship with food across the span of your life so far, you're not alone. But food isn't the enemy, it's what gives us the energy to function, plus if we allow it, it can be FUN, social & enjoyable.

Letting go of the food rules, the guilt, the expectations, the shame & finding the balance that works for ME has been so healing & life-changing. 

I really hope this encourages you to honour your hunger, listen to your cravings, fuel your body well & let go of any negative connotations you have when you think of food. It's not linear & it won't happen overnight, but it IS possible to allow food to simply be food.

Disclaimer: I don't eat the same meals every day, each day is different, but this was what I felt like on this particular day & I thought it would be fun to create a video showcasing the lightheartedness & enjoyment I now feel around eating :)

Doc ID: 12341, distribution: 0.284974001537103 ; She meant well when told me that she had been surprised to hear about my Struggle because, you just exude confidence.   I haven't stopped thinking about her words.  I wondered that I had looked in the mirror that very morning and wanted to climb back under my covers and hide from the world (because being aware of patriarchal beauty standards as socially constructed does not make it easier to not internalize them).   I wondered at how loud the fear was: I did not feel particularly confident that day. In fact, I felt scared and unsure about the future and finances and how anything would work out.  I wondered that appearing confident at all times meant to her that the trauma responses or eating disorder urges could not possibly exist in a Confident Body.   I think as a society we have such a limited understanding of mental health.   So here are some of my truths:  #: It's not about my body. Some days I struggle with body image, but some days I do not. It's rarely what drives my eating patterns, but my body can at times be a site of contention when it comes to feeling beautiful. While it's important to talk about it, I try not to center it in my discussions of eating disorders precisely because of the assumption that one must hate themselves or feel fat to deal with an ED. Those can absolutely be symptoms for some folks, but certainly not for everyone and they are rarely the root cause of the disorder.  #: So why do I have urges to restrict? Most often it is because trauma causes me to disconnect from my body, leading to me not take care of my body as I should. When Old Voices come calling, restricting caloric intake is a way to numb out / not feel / be out of my body.   #: Self-love and struggle can both exist. I can feel perfectly confident in who I am as a human some days, but that doesn't erase the struggle of living with c-ptsd or battling a Monster in my mind that tells me to escaping into the foggy haze of starvation again will solve my problems. I can love myself all the live long day, but I still have to learn how to cope in healthy ways with a brain that is a little bit broken (I say that in the sense of a broken leg, just for my brain) from past harm.   (Sometimes I feel like a broken record around this stuff, but I think it can be necessary to be repetitive when there is so much misinformation about there.) Doc ID: 9860, distribution: 0.4604773990187641 ; my final â€œall inâ€ update:

if you don't know what i'm talking about, in september, i decided to go â€œall inâ€ which has now become a popular recovery term, so let me give you a summary of what â€œall inâ€ was to ME. i had recovered from my eating disorder a few months PRIOR to deciding to go â€œall inâ€ (i say this b/c at the time, i felt comfortable eating all foods, didn't experience food guilt, wasn't battling my ed voice anymore, etc.), but i chose to start an â€œall inâ€ journey aka eating until complete fullness and whenever i even *thought* about wanting food and accepting any and all weight gain that came along with that because even though i felt free around food, i felt really out of tune with my body.  i hardly ever felt truly satiated, thought about food often in between eating, had no sex drive, got cold easy, had irregular periods, and was always tired, so i decided to go â€œall inâ€ even if that meant gaining excess weight with the goal of feeling my best.

i haven't talked about my â€œall inâ€ journey in a while because tbh, i hardly think about it. i hardly think about what i eat in general anymore because food no longer takes up more mental space than it needs to.  over the course of the past  months, i gained weight and also gained so much more awareness of and confidence in myself, and i feel the best i have in years. i still eat past fullness sometimes, emotionally eat, and have days where i overthink what i want to eat, but nobody's perfect, and there's beauty in that.  i'm not â€œendingâ€ my process because eating whatever i want whenever i want has just become more of a lifestyle choice that works for me.

since â€œall inâ€ has become really popular in the eating disorder recovery community, i also wanted to say to those of you who are recovering that there's no right or wrong way to recover.  recovery is so individual. no matter if you're going â€œall inâ€, following a meal plan, in treatment, or taking things one step at a time, you are choosing to fight and that's what matters most. it's so important in recovery AND life to not compare your journey to anyone else's, to stay in your own lane, and to do what works and is best for YOU.

Doc ID: 15417, distribution: 0.6769678963443987 ; Question: What's your view on full recovery from eating disorders? Do you think it's possible or do you see it more as remission or something you'll always live with? Do you think there's still progress for you to make or this is as good as it gets? Are you at peace with where you're at or do you find it impacts your life too much still? Sorry for the many questions! Xxx Answer: I know there's different views on this and I'm happy for others to take a different view to me. I don't think there's a point where you say Bam! That's full recovery! and then off you go into the world and never think of any eating related struggles again. However I definitely believe people can get to a point where they no longer meet the official diagnostic criteria for an eating disorder. So I suppose it depends on what you class as recovery.For me, I would be daft to take my eye off the recovery ball. If I were to say I am recovered and then I get complacent about monitoring myself, it could be a slippery slope back into disordered behaviours. I'm % at peace with where I'm at. There's bits I would like to sort out, but I could live the rest of my life being ok with where things are now. I'm working on those bits in therapy right now.Personally I think there are some unrealistic ideas about recovery out there. This idea that you will be able to eat whatever you like and never think about it, the idea that if you ever find yourself saying No thankyou to extras or to dessert you need to push through that, etc etc. That's not normal eating. Normal eating does require an element of mindfulness. I'm mindful about what my children eat, are they having adequate fruit and vegetables, are they eating balanced meals, do they enjoy sweet things without going crazy over them and so on, and I apply that same mindfulness to my own eating. There's more to nutrition than just weight. We don't know what is going on inside us and we have to respect our bodies if we want them to stay healthy  into old age.Having said that, none of that means that if someone needs to weight restore they shouldn't get on and do it by whatever means works for them. 
------------------------------------------------------------

Doc ID: 15860, distribution: 0.5347468429607387 ; Question: What was it that made you choose and do recovery. I'm on the fence all the time and wonder what is it that will give me that push to choose full on recovery.  Answer: I don't think there was ever a magic moment where I said right! everything is recovery from this point! When I started therapy, all I wanted to do was get control over my bingeing and purging. I wanted to be able to eat like a normal person - go out for a meal without it turning into a disaster. I didn't want to stop restricting or gain any weight though. Gradually as one aspect improved and I felt better, I was motivated to work on the next thing. I discovered how nice it was to live without all the negative impacts of restriction - to feel warm again! to not be snappy with my family! That motivated me not to fall back and to keep pressing forward.My therapist has been a big help, gently pushing me forward all the time and holding my progress when I slip back.I think what I'm saying is for some people there is a moment where they fully commit to full recovery and just go for it, and that's fantastic. I'm more of a little by little person, so taking baby steps towards recovery worked better for me. I feel like it's built me a solid foundation so that even when I slip, I have lots of ground underneath to catch me. Different things work for different people so only you know what will work for you and also you may need some trial and error to see what that is. But don't do nothing! Take the risk and try something and see how it goes. If it doesn't feel right at least on some level, try something else. Go for it x

Doc ID: 12525, distribution: 1.0 ; [tw: eating disorder] I cried for the entirety of our fifty minute therapy session, crumpled tissues piling high next to me, after she asked me what it was exactly about the eating disorder that I did not want to go back to.  As I described to her in between sobs what is is to survive ten years of violence inflicted upon your own body, something inside of me seemed to break. Remembering the nights of raw throated agony as I kneeled before a toilet bowl to pay my penance for my sins / the days of primal hunger as my stomach burned and my muscles ached, there was a sense of sheer terror that I would ever return to that life of suffering. And yet it pulls at me, the Monster, always calling me backwards towards sickness, towards dying, towards pain. It roars in my head that there is something unclean running through my veins that must be dug out; that I have, merely by existing, perpetrated the greatest of all crimes, transgressed the laws of the gods, and I must spend the rest of my days on my knees repenting. I have spent a lifetime, all of my short twenty-six years on this earth, atoning for sins that I have never even committed.  Are the gods satisfied yet?  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â â€¦.. â€œMaybe,â€ she says slowly, weighing her words, â€œmaybe, you have suffered enough.â€ I grab another tissue and hug my knees to my chest. It is deeply violent to deprive your body of the necessary calories it needs to survive, to heave and convulse before a toilet bowl altar, to run until your body is on the verge of collapse. What is it to live through trauma that is of your own making? What is it to live through such extreme violence at your own hands?  For so long I have numbed myself to the reality of what I was doing, but I felt the gravity of it all in that moment, telling her about how I used to lay in bed, counting my too-slow heartbeats to make sure I was still alive, all the while praying that I was not. Because, I tell her, to wake up and live another day meant listening to the Monster's orders, being a slave to Its sadistic whims and I couldn't bear that one more day.  I choke down more tears.  Reliving those days, those haunted days, brings up gut-wrenching pain. Yet I have begun to listen to the Monster again lately, buying into Its silver-tongued promises and rose-colored visions of safety and control. I know better, know that the life it offers is a life against my values.  But It's just one snack.  One run. One meal. One day. One week. One life. And I can feel myself falling again, spiraling into the dark place where I cannot choose for myself but can only obey / obey / obey the Monster.  This is not the life that I want. I don't want to go back to living as the dead, to walking around half-girl, half-ghost. I am terrified of being forced into living against myself again, committing violence against my body, directed by my mind.  She tells me that I have a choice in this, that I am giving away my power too easily, and I don't know that I believe her. I want to, but it doesn't feel true.  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  â€¦.. Just eat your food, Lindsay, I tell myself, eat your damn food.  I am sitting at a restaurant with friends, smiling and laughing and talking as though I were not starving myself to death.  The full plate of food in front of me makes my stomach growl and the hunger pangs grow stronger.  I can hear the therapist's voice in my head, Think about the life that you want. This is not what you want.  But the voice of the Monster is loud and strong, and I feel small and weak in comparison.  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  â€¦.. â€œI don't know how to want to eat,â€ I tell her.  â€œYou won't want to,â€ she says, â€œYou just have to go through the motions for a while before it gets easier.â€  I open the door to the refrigerator, close it, and then open it again.  I do not want to eat. But I am so very tired of pain, always pain. I am so very tired of dying.  I am so very tired of the hellish existence that is my eating disorder. I get out a plate. I make no promises for tomorrow, I tell her. I'm not committing myself to recovery and rainbows and sunshine. I don't know that I am even capable of beating back the Monster for any extended length of time. The Monster's grip on me is tight. Doc ID: 9767, distribution: 1.0 ; my life is not even close to â€œperfectâ€, it's not very exciting, and i am definitely not happy and joyful all the time, but at the end of the day, i love it and am so grateful for it.

sometimes i forget all the pain and hardship that i've been through to get to where i am now. while i still struggle with mental health and have moments when life feels really hard, i can confidently say that my low points now are still better than my high points when i was in the depths of my eating disorder.

it can be easy to romanticize eating disorders and to think that times when you were thinner or had a sense of control, life was better. i know i've had those thoughts. truth is, life for me during my eating disorders sucked pretty hard. i was a manipulative liar, i missed out on so many experiences that i will never get to have, i couldn't develop long-lasting relationships, i was in a toxic relationship with myself, and my entire mind was consumed by thoughts around food, my body, and numbers.

when things get hard now, remember to keep choosing LIFE. going backwards isn't an option, so what are you going to with your next step forward? there is so much life out there, and you deserve to live it, like really truly live it, to its fullest. i promise the fight to break free is worth it.

Doc ID: 12465, distribution: 1.0 ; In the past, some of my logic for staying stuck in the eating disorder was,Â â€œBut what if life doesn't get better afterwards? Like what if I recover / weight restore / stop using X behavior and life is still awful, but I just have no way to cope with it?â€ And I was surprised how many times in treatment I heard a similar sentiment from my peers. I remember a friend talking about how she was so afraid that the trauma and pain and misery would still be present if she let go of using disordered behaviors that she would rather stay in the misery she knew - a familiar, safe misery. Â  We had both staying in theÂ hell for fear that there was hell on the other side.Â  But what if we were wrong? I know, I know, you may not fully buy that, but hear me out: What if?Â  Hold space for that question for a moment: What if your vision of the future right now is distorted, because the fog of the disorder is so heavy around your mind that you can't see clearly what's ahead of you? What if you recover and let go and it's not more pain? What if you can create a life that you actually want to present in, one in which you don't have to numb out constantly just to survive?Â  Here's what I'm not saying: life will be pain-free and sparkly-glittery-unicorns every second of every day. Life is complex and filled with all kinds of experiences, but Y'ALL. What if we were wrong about everything? What if there is actually so much goodness ahead of us? Â Isn't that worth fighting for? Isn't it worth fighting with every ounce of energy we have left in our tired bodies to get to the other side?Â  It's easier to succumb to the siren song of the disorder, a song of protection from pain and numbness to the trauma we've faced. I'm not asking you to commit to recovery or give up your self-destructive behaviors. I'm asking you to consider, even just for a second: What if you were wrong about hope?

EAT SOMETHING SMALL AGAIN. dont beat yourself up. if you binge, you binge. stay present. pay attention to how your body feels, not how you feel. if you feel full, wait. give your digestive system a chance to digest and adjust and keep up. its been through a lot so your signals may be all out of wack and you may feel terrible but you must perservere because theres actuallya science to pacing yourself and if you can commit to this for just a little bit youll start to notice small results and then you turn that into momentum!!if your body's signals are screwy from years and months of abuse, you must override with the power of the brain. force yourself to eat small meals often, dont let your ghrelin and leptin dictate if you know better that they are off. take the pain, be present in it, remember if for next time. if you can get thru this your body will come round eventually and youll be able to start gauging hunger more accurately.. which helps when you're working on control of portions (not over or under eating) because you dont have to think about control at this point - eventually you'll be able to relinquish that control and just listen to your body. but for now you gotta know better. i realize this might not be entirely helpful but its the best advice i got. restricting and bingeing is a cyclic hell and its very hard to break but not impossible and believing you can is a very powerful component to accomplishing this. i wish u the best of luck anon ğŸ–¤and im sorry if this tangent wasnt helpful

Doc ID: 9914, distribution: 1.0 ; i've still been â€œall inâ€, but i don't really think of it like that anymore because it's just become my normal way of eating.
â€”â€”
when blake and i spend evenings together (most nights), he sits in the kitchen when i cook myself extra meals (or cooks them for me) and walks to chipotle with me when i want a burrito bowl as a snack.  sometimes, he'll eat these extra meals or snacks with me, but a lot of times he doesn't and just gives me company. do i get bothered that i eat significantly more than him even though he's got  inches and  pounds on me? no, because i know our body's dietary needs are SO individual, and if i want food, it doesn't make sense not to go get some.
â€”â€”
i remember reading something along the lines of:

feeling hungry is like the urge to pee- it's your body's signal of telling you what it needs. if you honor your body by going to the bathroom when it needs to go, why don't you honor your body and eat when it needs food?

next time you catch yourself comparing what you eat to what someone else eats, feeling like you â€œshouldn'tâ€ eat more, or judging yourself for eating, ask yourself â€œdo i judge myself when I need to pee more than someone else? do i beat myself up every time i feel the urge to go? do i think it's better to push off peeing until you just can't hold it any longer?â€ if you answer no, why don't you apply that same logic to feeling hungry?
â€”â€”
p.s. i know the comparison isn't exactly equal, and there's a lot of additional science that i'm not acknowledging here, but i found this comparison to be light-hearted, easy to comprehend, and possibly helpful in moments of doubt, so i thought i'd share :)

To be honest it's weird to say I'm an â€œinfluencerâ€ even after almost three years of doing this. When I'm in my off-the-Internet  life and I'm asked about my in-the-net work, I suddenly feel thrown off. Like there's this person I have to conjure up to relate to what I think they know about me. Like I have to be who they expect me to be because they've seen my page before. But that gets so exhausting so fast. It's not that i am someone totally different on IG, or fake or pretending to be someone I'm not, it's just that I regularly feel like conforming to an image I've made of myself. Sometimes I feel like when ppl talk to me who don't hang out with me regularly don't really know me... but that's not their fault. It's me just trying to be something likeable to the masses. Doc ID: 16676, distribution: 0.534420263943577 ; Therapy .. // holiday eating  T asked me how my eating had been on holiday. I said how in the desert it had been good. I don't know if it's unhealthy to justify it like this but it was the reality of the situation. Lunch and dinner there was always loads of vegetables and I made sure I ate some protein as well, although the amount of that available was limited but I did eat adequate amounts. I just tended to avoid the carbs, although I always had some bread. I said I hadn't found the eating difficult, I was always full after meals, and I hadn't felt like I was obsessing over food between meals or feeling unwell or any of the other things that tend to happen when I'm restricting. I told her how it got harder when we came out of the desert because maybe I had gradually built up a calorie deficit and my body was trying to catch up now more food was available. I tried to explain how awful and out of control it feels when my brain and body are working against each other, even if I kind of know what's going on, it's hard to trust either my brain or my body, and I end up having all sorts of urges. At least I could honestly say I hadn't been purging (vomiting) despite having a lot of thoughts about it. The main thing that stopped me is that I haven't done it for so long now that I would be so mad with myself if I took that massive step backwards, and I know it would start a downward spiral. It's just shameful to think about it afterwards though and think how tempting it felt. I did manage to confess rather shamefully to what I'd ended up doing (chewing and spitting) and how things were a bit rough but I figure I just need to ride it out and I will come through it and back into a settled pattern of eating soon enough [which a week later, I have] We got through all that and to a bit of a pause, and after a bit of silence T said â€œDo you want to keep talking about food or do you want to talk about something else?â€ I thought for a bit and said that I didn't think that I had anything more to say about food but I wasn't sure what else to talk about. â€œBecause you have too many options?â€ T asked. â€œNo, I just don't know what to talk about.â€ â€œOkâ€¦ so we could talk about what is happening with dâ€¦ or we could talk about your letter to your mumâ€¦â€

Doc ID: 9457, distribution: 1.0 ; how can you feel like your body is your home if you're viewing it as a temporary place to live?

i'm not anti-having body-related goals, and i believe in body autonomy, but i also think there are a lot of people who use trying to manipulate and change their bodies as a way to try and find self-love and self-acceptance when true self-love and self-acceptance are not things that come from being a certain size or fitting into a certain image or box.

i spent a lot of years at war with my body, constantly blaming my body, resenting my body, and trying to control my body. i viewed my body as being separate from me and something that was temporary. the truth i had to face was that whether i liked what i saw in the mirror or not, i only ever have one body, and it's the forever home to my soul. 

you can't hate yourself or your body into a person or body you love, and the only way to really feel at home and comfortable in your skin is through unconditional acceptance.

loving your body isn't about loving how it looks all the time. gentle reminder that you don't have to love how your body looks to choose to take care of it, be kind to it, nourish it, and accept it.

Doc ID: 9468, distribution: 0.43588539551270356 ; the way our brains work and their ability to unlearn and learn new thought patterns never cease to amaze me.

it's wild and incredible thinking about how i used to be OBSESSED about food and my body and felt the need to plan out my meals DAYS in advance and how i now unconditionally accept my body without second thought (i don't always â€œloveâ€ it, but i always accept it) and don't usually know what i'm eating for dinner until dinner time comes.

i remember so clearly thinking full freedom wasn't possible for me, and that being where i am now would never happen. yet, here i am after a lot of non-linear healing and can confidently say recovery IS possible and IS worth it.

here's a list of some the things i love most about no longer dieting and some reasons why you should keep going in your recovery:

- going out to eat at a restaurant and ordering what sounds good in the moment without having to look up calories or macros in advance
- having the energy and mental space to do the things that are important to me
- not having a number on the scale dictate how my mood is gonna be that day
- eating ice cream whenever i feel like it without any feelings of guilt or shame
- finding joy in exercise and moving in ways that feel good for me
- having an abundance mindset around food and not having to bring â€œsafeâ€ snacks with me everywhere
- being able to connect with people more
- not having my life consumed with thoughts about food and my body

if you need to hear this reminder: the rules, beliefs, and messages about food and bodies that were engrained into your brain for years aren't just going to get unlearned and replaced overnight. keep going in your healing. i promise it's worth it.

p.s. the cheese tortellini from @miabellarestaurant is the best pasta dish in cleveland. bold statement, i know, but it's really that good.

Doc ID: 7299, distribution: 0.6455815493791777 ; my recovery from my eating disorder was a time in my life marked by loss, release, and acceptance.

i personally struggled with restrictive eating and overexercising. every eating disorder looks different, and not all include these elements. this is my story. it's one tale of thousands.

when i committed to my truest recovery, i had to gain a significant amount of weight to restore my body's health and functioning. i swore i could accomplish this while also holding onto all of the toxic behaviors that got me to this point. i was in denial. i insisted i could have it all.

i wanted to gain weight and recover and still eat diet-esque â€œsafeâ€ foods. i wanted to gain weight and recover and still work out every single day. i pleaded with my parents and treatment team. i justified my choices. looking back, i can't believe i kept a straight face as i begged them to let me work out â€œbecause i just love it so muchâ€.

you know when i finally recovered? when i healed my relationship with food and exercise. and you know when i did THAT? when i finally let go of my need for control, surrendered my obsessions, and accepted my reality. when i finally shut up and followed my meal plan. when i finally shut up and complied with a  month total exercise restriction.

this comes from a place of love, but that love is tough love. if you loved â€œeating healthyâ€ and â€œworking outâ€ for the ACTUAL RIGHT REASONS, you'd be willing to give up your control around them if it meant finding true health and happiness. the right reasons to love these things are simple: you love to eat well and move because these acts contribute to a sense of peace and serenity within. if you're using either of these to hurt yourself, how can you love them for the right reasons? you simply can't. it's time to be real and face all the irrational lies.

there's no healing without loss, release, and acceptance. all discomfort is temporary. it simply can't be avoided. please stop fighting yourself...it's just ğŸ‘ not ğŸ‘ worth it.

The biggest hurdle but the most important step to recovery, is letting go of a sick body. You NEED to gain, you need to let go of controlling your body. A healthy body is nourished. A healthy brain doesnt obsess over sizes and numbers. Its not that simple yes it is. Eat. Force your Ed to shut the fuck up. Cry if you need. Scream if you need. But just fucking eat. Your emotional well being, physical wellbeing, and mental health will all improve as you begin actually feeding your brain and body. Duh. Fucking duh. I absolutely see where you're coming from, and being where you're supposed to be physically works wonders on your mind - but in order to really let go of a sick body, you'll need more than just nutritional restoration. I knew I had to eat enough to keep my body alive for years, but the lack of resources for my mindset just invalidated the hell out of me and kept me sicker. You can't recover without taking care of the physical aspect first, but that can only go so far without needing mental help to cope with all of that.If I'm taking your post too literally, I apologize.
I definitely think getting therapy cannot be ignored in recovery. Absolutely people need mental help to get better. Its the physical part a lot of people tend to slack on. Just therapy isnt enough. You cant heal unless you work on both your brain and your body. 
------------------------------------------------------------
Doc ID: 24571, distribution: 0.3245426902386565 ; Question: I feel like I  no longer care about losing or gaining weight,I just want to reach the point where I can be the way I used it to be and go to parties and dress slutty and all that without worrying about my appearance or unvoluntarily compare myself to all the girls who are way more attractive than I will ever be.But everytime I try to wear what I love I just feel hideous and I crawl back into baggy shit to hide my body(ik I'm a healthy weight but still) Answer: ahhhhh. the lasting effects of the ed :( you can be psychologically past the point of caring about size, yet the confidence still evades you. i know this  too well. shit is hard. and society doesnt really help when it comes to perpetuating a space where we all already are going to feel like this. this is one of those things that just takes time. it takes hating yourself, to find love for yourself. it takes hating and loving others, to find love for yourself. its something that you gotta find, but you gotta find it from within. everything that is external can either distract from or help you realize your potential. but accepting and loving that potential is ultimately in inner working. this is something im still working on. if you feel hideous, sometimes you just gotta accept that you think you feel hideous. wear what you love anyways. if you love it, thats THAT bitch. wear the pieces because you love them, not yourself. chances are if you do that, people will love it feel like for u personally anon if you have tried psychedlics yet, and you've ever considered them / have been interested - now might be a good time to try them. responsibly of course, for healing and inner wisdom purposes - not for recreation lol. if you do psychs at a party they wont allow u to have a good time but if knowledge and love of self is what you seek - mushrooms have helped me tremendously in this department. idc if this sounds shallow but english words cant even articulate how powerful these plants/fungi can be for people. the drugs dont make you enlightened, but they allow your brain to actually established new neural pathways (science did a brain scan okay if anyone wants proof i will go out of my way to post it) but these drugs allow you to ACTUALLY shift your perspective and think differently, which is helpful if you are stuck in a rut and need a nudge from your higher self. psychs just kinda make you open to that, nothing more. its not a cure and its not instant but they are tools and teachers when used correctly can save lives. i know they saved mine. anyhow i think you're ready if this is somethin you've ever been receptive to. your intention is all there. loving yourself is not without of reach. currently i wear baggy clothes most of the time, dont hide. you cant. do it because theyre comfy and feel good yano. wear WHATEVER u want bc it feels good. thats the only reason you need.

Doc ID: 24773, distribution: 0.47249430541476883 ; Question: The worst thing about trying to recover from an eating disorder is that you have no clue what a normal amount of food is I feel so pathetic to think that I'm this grown and I don't know how much to fucking eat Just like a toddler... (My case at least) Answer: i feel u tho /: my last bad lapse i went about â€¦ ehh i cant remember - months barely eating and i was on the brink of dysfunction, had no idea what to eat or how, couldnt find the motivation. my dad actually offered to meal prep for me every day, just so i could get something in me. they were super small portions (â€œsafeâ€ if u will) and at first i wouldnt always finish everything bc my stomach was so shrunken.  itd be like a small handful of grapes, small handful of almonds, a protein bar or a piece of dark chocolate, and a small hunk of bread & pb to dip.. just small amounts of easy digestible shit i could get down without having to think about it or make any decisions about preferences. eventually i got some energy back after refeeding for a few weeks and i was able to prepare all my snack box stuff on my own and eventually i started cooking again and now i cool regular bomb ass meals and a lotof stuff is from scratch. im pretty quick n efficient and i can survive now, i dont even know how i was scraping by previous to that. you just work your way up there. whatever your body can physically do. when you're recovering from an eating disorder you're â€œnot normalâ€ by default so dont worry about normal portions. â€œnormal portionsâ€ in america are often grandiose n huge n exagerrated so dont pay attn to nothin but what ur body tells you!! you have to simultaneously push yourself without pushing yourself too much. if u dont have the means or motivation to see a nutritionist (a nutritionist was relatively helpful in helping me get past bulimia) they arent necessary if ur rly focused on getting better. but then again sometimes u absolutely need somebody to intervene. its ok to ask for help. let it be known that ive basically always been forced at the end of my ropes to get help bc i break down noticeably n everyone can tell but i personally SUCK at asking for help (#hypocrate) but looking back its likeâ€¦ dude why waste your life and time. people r willing to help n often times they wanna help. theres a lot of good information on youtube and google about food n feelings n portions if ur not rly sure what ur tryna do. dont feel pathetic for bein afflicted mate, if you're aware of a problem you're already a step into tackling it thats how i look at it so yâ€¦ea. sorry for the longwinded response its hard for me togive str fwd answers hopefully that got some sort of gist across

Doc ID: 23413, distribution: 0.5462991692809371 ; Question: I was on a diet for a long time and nothing happened weight wise. As result, I am probably developing an eating disorder. I am still able to mostly eat what I want but also alter between binging and outright skipping meals. My psychologist suggested eating something every three hours but that just makes me feel like I'm over eating by a huge amount as I seem to be unable to control my portion size : every few hours isnt bad. That doesnt mean you have to eat a meal every few hours, you could literally have a piece of fruit or some pretzels in between meals. Sometimes i get extra hungry and eat like  meals a day. Who cares.  Just munching isnt bad. Some days i have  full meals. Some days i sleep in and just graze on snacks all day long. Like who cares. My body will handle it. Yes some medications have an effect on appetite. You can always talk with your medical team about it and see what they suggest. Sometimes i cant tell if im hungry and some times i cant tell if im full. Thats just how it be. Finding a routine can be helpful. Breakfast, snacky, lunch, snacky, dinner. Maybe another snack at night if you feel like it because why not. Eating with other people can be helpful, i tend to go werewolf when i eat alone. With pals i feel more relaxed and less likely to tie my mental and emotional state with my eating. Bro(and/or sis) never be afraid to speak up about these issues. Ask questions. Talk about concerns. To your family, your friends, your doctors, people who can be there with you in person to help. Literally no reason to face this alone. At all. Maybe consider writing your thoughts and feelings in a journal and tracking whats going on in your life and in your head when you have bad food days. Thats a good first step. You can use that as a guide to talk to a professional about whats happening. Or just to talk to a trusted family member (someone old enough to actually help you)If you feel a need to use behaviors â€œi want to skip mealsâ€ â€œi want to binge eatâ€ etc, ask yourself .. Why?Work on fixing the â€œwhyâ€ and then you wont have the need to use behaviors. The sooner you work on yourself the better. Take care!!!! Good luck! Reach out to others!!! Hit me up if you ever need. Edit: i thought of this after hitting send. You can try those plates that have the dividers in them to help with eyeballing portion sizes.

Doc ID: 6256, distribution: 0.6756847392335479 ; Eric Dorsa, a Recovery Ambassador Council member at @eatingrecovery, shares how he reclaimed power from his Eating Disorder:â£
â£
"I used to think that recovery was getting to a place in my life where I was no longer engaging in behaviors. I believed it to be the moment when I would love my body no matter what, and I would be happy and bullet proof and a self-help guru.â£
â£
I believed that recovery was this magical place where I would want â€œitâ€ all the time and I could see past all the pain and lies and trauma and be in the truth all the time. Believe me when I say this; I so wish at many times in my life that this was true. I wish this is what recovery looked like because at times, life in recovery is so painful.â£
â£
It is brutally honest and asks you to be brave. It is having to do things that have never been done before. It asks you to be the only one standing on the stage in a spotlight. It asks you to name every fear out loud to a complete stranger.â£
â£
On the other side of this journey that is never done is your freedom, your wisdom, you. On the other side of this pain is your truth! It is your superpower.â£
â£
You see, I needed every minute of my journey to realize that I get to live life now. And that is the most vulnerable thing I can do. I get to be me now, all of me if I want to. And believe me, I want nothing more." - @fkdrag

pumpkin pie banana bread

ingredients:

-  large bananas, mashed
- / cup pumpkin puree (not pumpkin pie filling)
-  eggs
- / cup olive oil
-  cup coconut sugar
- splash of vanilla
-  cups gluten free flour
- pinch each of sea salt, baking powder, cinnamon, pumpkin pie spice
- chocolate chips of choice
	
â€¨directions:

- preheat oven to F and grease a loaf tin. in a mixing bowl, combine the bananas, pumpkin, eggs, oil, vanilla, and sugar until uniform and well combined. add the remaining ingredients and fold everything together until a thick batter forms. stir through the chocolate chips, then transfer batter to the loaf tin and bake for - minutes or until golden brown. let cool completely before slicing!

chocolate chip zucchini banana bread

ingredients:
-  eggs
-  large mashed banana
- / cup almond butter 
- / cup maple syrup
- splash of vanilla
-  medium zucchini, shredded and then thoroughly drained/squeezed

-  / cups almond flour
-  tbsp coconut sugar
- pinch of cinnamon
- pinch of sea salt
- pinch of baking powder

- chocolate chips
â €
preheat oven to F. mix all wet ingredients in a bowl and place aside. shred the zucchini and squeeze out all the liquid. place aside.  in a separate bowl, mix all the dry ingredients. add the wet mixture to the dry and fold in to combine. lastly, add the zucchini and the chocolate chips and mix evenly. pour batter into a greased loaf pan with parchment paper,  bake for - minutes, or until golden brown. let cool completely before slicing!

chocolate ganache pumpkin brownies

ingredients:

-  eggs
- / cup maple syrup
- / cup pumpkin puree (not pumpkin pie filling)
-  tbsp melted coconut oil + / cup chocolate chips (melted until smooth)
- / cup cacao powder
-  tbsp coconut flour
- pinch each of sea salt and baking powder
- chocolate chips of choice

directions:

preheat oven to F and prepare a brownie pan. mix the eggs, syrup, and pumpkin until uniform. then stir through the melted chocolate and whisk until well combined. add the rest of the ingredients until a smooth, uniform batter forms. transfer this to the brownie pan and bake for - minutes. let cool before icing with the ganache.

 ingredient chocolate ganache

in a small bowl combine:

- / cup cacao powder
- / cup powdered sugar 
-  tbsp non-dairy milk

whisk until smooth and uniform, then spread over the brownies. place in the fridge to set before slicing!

quick and easy weeknight stew - eggplant, peeled and cubed
- red bell peppers, diced
- cup butternut squash chunks - can diced tomatoes
-/ cup tomato sauce
-/ cup vegetable broth - onion, diced
- cups spinach -sea salt
-garlic powder
- tbsp balsamic vinegar

set the oven to  and toss the butternut squash in oil and salt. lay on a parchment paper lined pan and roast for about  minutes. meanwhile sautÃ© the onion in a generous amount of olive oil and sea salt until browned. add the diced eggplant and a splash of water and cook until soft, about - minutes. add peppers and stir through for a minute. remove the squash from the oven (won't be fully roasted yet but will continue to cook on the stove) and add to the pot along with the tomatoes, sauce, broth, and seasonings/vinegar. bring heat to high and let boil, then reduce to a simmer and cook for about - minutes or plenty reduced. stir in the spinach at the very end.
.
.

 ingredient vegan vanilla peanut butter protein bars

- / cup creamy salted peanut butter 
- / cup plant based vanilla protein 
- / cup almond flour
- chocolate of choice â€¨

â–ªï¸â–ªï¸â–ªï¸â–ªï¸â–ªï¸â–ªï¸â–ªï¸â–ªï¸â–ªï¸â–ªï¸ extra fudgey brownies with chocolate mousse icing:

- / cup maple syrup
- / cup salted crunchy almond butter (can use any nut butter here, will change the flavor profile a bit)

- pinch of sea salt
- pinch of cinnamon (brings out chocolate flavor)

icing: - / cup full fat coconut milk
-  tbsp cacao powder
-  tbsp maple syrup
- / of a ripe avocado
- sea salt
- vanilla

blend until thick, will be mousse-like in texture. let set in the fridge for an hour or two before icing completely cooled brownies
.
.
.

/ cup cashew butter
 tbsp maple syrup
 tbsp almond milk
 tbsp oat flour

 tbsp chia seeds

extra fudgey brownies with chocolate mousse icing:

set oven to  and grease a brownie pan. 
to a bowl add  flax egg ( Tbsp ground flaxseed +   tbsp water). let sit until gel-like consistency. to that add: -  cup mashed sweet potato
- / cup maple syrup
- / cup salted crunchy almond butter (can use any nut butter here, will change the flavor profile a bit)
- splash of vanilla

mix until a well-combined, then add: - / cup cacao powder
- pinch of sea salt
- pinch of cinnamon (brings out chocolate flavor)

mix thoroughly until a thick batter forms. will seem a bit dry at first but keep mixing, it will come together! mix through chocolate of choice and transfer batter to the brownie pan. bake for - minutes. let cool completely before icing.

icing: - / cup full fat coconut milk
-  tbsp cacao powder
-  tbsp maple syrup
- / of a ripe avocado
- sea salt
- vanilla

blend until thick, will be mousse-like in texture. let set in the fridge for an hour or two before icing completely cooled brownies
.

PUMPKIN SPICED peanut butter oatmeal blondies with MAPLE CREAM CHEESE frosting (vegan, gluten and tree-nut free)

 cup runny peanut butter
/ cup pumpkin puree
splash of vanilla

 cup oat flour
/ cup sprouted oats
pinch of baking powder
sea salt
cinnamon
pumpkin pie spice
/ cup coconut flour

add the dry mixture on top of the wet, then mix again using the mixer on the lowest setting. slowly add in / cup of almond milk until the mixture moistens up and large clumps form. add more milk if needed! finally stir chocolate chips and pour mixture into a parchment paper lined brownie tin. bake at  for  minutes!

/ cup cashews soaked overnight
 tablespoons each: coconut sugar, maple syrup, warm water

VEGAN copycat cookie cake bars

set oven to . grease a loaf pan. in a small bowl, make a flax egg by mixing together  tbsp ground flax and . tbsp water. let sit until thick.

in a large bowl mix together:

- / cup coconut sugar
- / cup melted coconut oil
- splash of vanilla

ad the flax egg and stir until everything is thoroughly combined. then add:

-  cup almond flour
- pinch of sea salt
- pinch of baking powder

mix until a thick, sticky dough forms. fold through chocolate chips of choice, then cover bowl and place in fridge for  minutes.

meanwhile, in a food processor add:

- / cup almond butter
- / cup soft pitted dates
- pinch of sea salt

run the blender. after a few seconds, slowly pour in a tablespoon of warm water and let it run through the mixture. add one more if the blade isn't moving much! the mix here should be sticky and rollable, not watery.

add the almond butter/date mixture to the dough, the mix thoroughly with hands until sticky and well combined. if the batter is a dit dry, feel free to add up to  tbsp dairy free milk. stir through chocolate chips at this point as well! transfer dough to the loaf pan and press down until even. bake for about  minutes, then let cool completely before slicing
.
.

jumbo chocolate chip cookie dough cups

ingredients:

- / cup nut butter of choice (creamy and salted)
- / cup maple syrup
-  cup oat flour 
- pinch of sea salt

mix all of the above until a dough forms. if it's too runny add another tbsp of flour, and if it's too dry add a splash of almond milk! press the dough down into cupcake liners in a muffin tin. melt chocolate of choice and pour a generous amount on each cup. add chocolate chips and sea salt at the very end and freeze to set (about an hour or two). best enjoyed thawed from the freezer!

Doc ID: 6742, distribution: 0.9296470169548279 ; i've said it once, but life advice that bears constant repeating:

toast your banana bread.

leave it to me to bake up a fresh loaf before finding out that today is a national banana bread holiday ğŸ‘€ i love where my head is at hahaha

that being said, what better day than today to save this recipe and make it for later? i've tried hundreds of gluten free banana bread recipes over the years but i always come back to this one. i've never met a texture more perfect than this one!

and of course, once it's all baked up and cooled, you need to toss a thick slice in the toaster until golden brown, then top with some butter and chocolate chunks. i really can't emphasize enough how dreamy and satisfying each bite isâ€¦ wow. hope you try it out for yourself!

recipe for the loaf is below!

classic gluten-free banana bread

preheat oven to F and prepare a loaf pan.

wet ingredients:

-  large ripe bananas, mashed
- / cup olive oil 
-  eggs 
- / cup coconut syrup 
- splash of vanilla

dry ingredients:

-  cups gluten-free flour
- pinch each of sea salt, baking powder, and cinnamon 

mix the wet ingredients together until well-combined. in a separate bowl, do the same for the dry ingredients. add the dry mixture to the wet and fold until uniform. i stirred through about / cup candied pecans at the last minute :) transfer batter to the prepared loaf pan and bake for - minutes or until a toothpick comes out clean. let cool completely before slicing or icing. i iced mine with  cup powdered sugar mixed with  tbsp milk until a glaze formed, then poured over the top and let set in the fridge before slicing.

i teased this recipe awhile agoâ€” so excited to finally share it so we can all make it together ğŸ¥²

glazed chocolate orange loaf

ingredients:

-  ripe bananas, mashed
-  eggs
- / cup vegan melted butter 
-  tbsp maple syrup
- / cup orange juice
- splash vanilla extract
-  cup almond flour
-  cup gluten free flour blend 
- pinch of sea salt, baking powder, and cinnamon
-  chopped dark chocolate bar

preheat oven to F and grease a loaf tin. add all of the wet ingredients and mix until combined. then add in the dry ingredients and mix until uniform. careful to fold and not over mix! stir through chopped chocolate and transfer batter into the loaf tin. bake for about - mins or until golden brown. let cool completely. 

once cool, top with melted chocolate. slice and enjoy!

vanilla maple glazed gingerbread loaf

ingredients: 

-  tablespoons unsalted butter (melted)
-  eggs

- / cup vanilla yogurt of choice
- / cup pumpkin puree (not pumpkin pie filling
-  cup gluten free flour
- / cup almond flour
- pinch each of baking powder, sea salt, cinnamon, and ground nutmeg

directions:

whisk until well combined. add the rest of the ingredients until a smooth, uniform batter forms. transfer this to the brownie pan and bake for - minutes. let cool before icing with the ganache.

preheat oven to F and prepare a loaf tin. mix the butter, eggs, sugar, and molasses until fluffy, then add in the yogurt and and pumpkin and whisk until uniform. stir through the remaining ingredients and fold until well combined. transfer the batter to the loaf tin and bake for - minutes. let cool before icing.

vanilla maple glaze

-  cup powdered sugar
-  tbsp milk of choice
-  tbsp maple syrup
- splash of vanilla
	
whisk until uniform, then pour over the cooled loaf! let set before slicing.
